SpNote.title: Please read
SpNote.note:
A note abouts notes -------------------
This is a note outlining good practice in note writing for heterodyne MSB. PLEASE replace this note with your own note or delete altogether BEFORE submitting the MSB.
Things to include in your notes -------------------------------
* Calibration details
1) Overall observing strategy for your science program. A paragraph conveying the general ideas behind your science program is useful for the observer (who may not be an expert in your field) and the TSS.
2) Details of calibration observations. Unlike SCUBA MSBs, heterodyne MSBs have no explicit calibration component. Spell out any specific calibrations you require a the note which is selected as "show-to-observer". Example instructions might include:
"Perform a spectral line fivepoint on a nearby pointing source."
and/or
"Short sample on a nearby spectral line standard with a good CO(3-2) line e.g. OMC1".
and/or
"Short sample on a point-like planet (e.g. Uranus), with same backend set up as science target."
In short, you'll at least want something to check back-end setup and receiver performance (e.g. a spectral line standard), and something to enable you to convert the measured antenna temperature to an astrophysical brightness temperature (e.g. a planet).
Things that shouldn't appear in notes -------------------------------------
1) There is no need to repeat information in notes that is already included in other components of the MSB. This might include receiver tunings, chop throws, offset positions and science targets. All of these should be set up in the appropriate MSB components. If they are reproduced in notes, there is a risk that changes made to main body of the MSB will not be reflected in the notes, leading to conflicts between the notes and the MSB components resulting in confusion at the telescope.
